news_summary: The new UK online safety law promises to enhance internet security by protecting users from harmful content and promoting safer digital experiences. This legislation marks a significant step forward in safeguarding human rights online and fostering a more secure, responsible internet environment.
news_summary_fr: La nouvelle loi britannique sur la sécurité en ligne promet de renforcer la sécurité de l'internet en protégeant les utilisateurs contre les contenus préjudiciables et en promouvant des expériences numériques plus sûres. Cette législation marque une avancée significative dans la sauvegarde des droits de l'homme en ligne et dans la promotion d'un environnement Internet plus sûr et plus responsable.
news_summary_es: La nueva ley de seguridad en línea del Reino Unido promete mejorar la seguridad en internet protegiendo a los usuarios de contenidos nocivos y fomentando experiencias digitales más seguras. Esta legislación supone un importante paso adelante para salvaguardar los derechos humanos en línea y fomentar un entorno de internet más seguro y responsable.

articles.title: UK online safety law is going to change the way we use the internet
articles.summary: The UK's Online Safety Act is intended to stop children from accessing pornography online, but its potential implications are much wider reaching
articles.content:
The UK's Online Safety Act is intended to stop children from accessing pornography online, but its potential implications are much wider reaching

Using the internet in the UK will soon mean having to verify your age to access certain services Luis Alvarez/Getty Images

If you live in the UK, the way you access the internet is about to fundamentally change. A new law, the Online Safety Act, comes into force on 25 July and will see a broad range of online providers asking UK users to verify their age through selfies, ID documents and other methods in order to access particular services. Other countries are watching closely, and may follow suit, potentially bringing about a huge change to the way we operate online.

What is the Online Safety Act?

The law is intended to protect children from being exposed to harmful content online. That involves blocking them from accessing pornography and also content that encourages self-harm, depicts violence or encourages dangerous stunts.

Such content remains legal for adults to access online, but they will now have to prove how old they are to do so – which isn’t currently routine. The law is also intended to prevent the spread of illegal content, ranging from child sexual abuse to fraud to terrorism.

Ella Bradshaw at the UK’s National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC) says it is like bringing the internet in line with the sale of alcohol or cigarettes in the real world. “Adults have to prove who they are in a safe, privacy-preserving way all the time. I see this more as a culture change to fix this lag we’ve had online,” she says.

When does it take effect?

The deadline for complying with the legislation is 25 July, but its effects have already been felt. In the past few months, many small websites have shut down rather than risk falling foul of the legislation, which can impose fines of up to £18 million or 10 per cent of global revenue, whichever is larger.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Daily The latest on what’s new in science and why it matters each day. Sign up to newsletter

More recently, big websites have been announcing how they are going to meet the act’s obligations, and most of them plan to use third-party age verification tools. Earlier this week, Reddit began checking the age of users from the UK using a tool called Persona, while Bluesky will be using a service called Kids Web Services. Bluesky says that anyone who isn’t verified will be blocked from adult content and also won’t be allowed to use direct messaging. Major pornography sites like PornHub have also said they will introduce age verification.

So how do you verify your age online?

One thing is for sure, clicking a button that says “I am over 18” is no longer going to cut it. The UK regulator Ofcom will be in charge of enforcing the act, and it has made it clear that more rigorous checks will be needed. These may take the form of uploading scans of government ID documents or using AI face recognition that determines whether the person in front of a camera is 18 or not.

Persona, for example, requires users to either upload a photograph of themselves or a photo of a driving licence or passport. Reddit won’t have access to that data, and Persona promises to delete it within a week after performing age verification. New Scientist asked Persona to explain the process, but the company wasn’t able to comment before publication.

Should we be wary of age verification?

Alan Woodward at the University of Surrey in the UK says that trusting websites – particularly those “dubious by nature”, like pornography publishers – directly with your data is less than ideal. But that being sent to a site’s chosen third party verification tool also gives you little control over who you have to share your data with. He says the government could step in and run verification itself, but then there are still privacy issues with telling the state which websites you frequent.

“Personally, I would minimise giving any information online that is not strictly necessary,” says Woodward. “I think the AI-based facial age verification is probably the best way through this minefield.”

Will age verification work?

It is relatively easy for websites and online services to tell where users are based, meaning that UK users can be made to verify their age and others won’t need to. But some people could use tools called virtual private networks (VPNs) to appear as if they are based elsewhere to circumvent the checks. These aren’t a niche product: almost half of internet users in the UK have used one.

“VPNs are lawful services that can be used by people in the UK. While age assurance will make the online space safer for children, it is not a silver bullet. We recognise that determined teenagers may well find ways to access online pornography,” says a spokesperson for Ofcom. “Our guidance is clear that platforms must not host, share or permit content that encourages use of VPNs as a way to get around online safety measures.”

What will all of this mean for people outside the UK?

Other countries are also introducing or investigating similar measures to the UK. In France, large pornography websites are being made to verify their users’ ages, while Australia plans to ban social media for under-16s. At a certain point, it may become easier for websites to check everyone’s age rather than try to selectively apply the patchwork of international legislation.
articles.reasoning: The UK's Online Safety Act aims to protect children from harmful online content and illegal material, which is a positive government policy benefiting citizens by enhancing online safety. While there are concerns about privacy and implementation challenges, the overall intent to safeguard vulnerable users and promote safer internet use is hopeful and constructive.
articles.personality_title: UK’s new online safety law aims to protect children and reshape internet use
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Starting July 25, the UK will introduce a new law called the Online Safety Act. This law is designed to make the internet a safer place, especially for children who could accidentally come across harmful content.

**What happened**
Under this new law, many online services will ask users in the UK to verify their age before accessing certain types of content. The main goal is to stop children from seeing inappropriate material, like pornography, while also targeting illegal and harmful content.

**Impact**
This change means safer online experiences for young people and helps protect vulnerable users. While some worry about privacy and how the law will be put into practice, the overall hope is that the internet will become a more secure and trustworthy space for everyone.

**What's next step**
Online companies will start updating their systems to include age verification for UK users. Users can expect to see new prompts or checks when visiting certain websites or online services.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The UK's Online Safety Act promises to make the internet safer for children by introducing age checks and protecting users from harmful content.
articles.personality_title_fr: La nouvelle loi sur la sécurité en ligne du Royaume-Uni vise à protéger les enfants et à remodeler l'utilisation d'Internet
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
À partir du 25 juillet, le Royaume-Uni présentera une nouvelle loi appelée la loi sur la sécurité en ligne. Cette loi est conçue pour faire d'Internet un endroit plus sûr, en particulier pour les enfants qui pourraient accidentellement trouver un contenu nocif.

**ce qui s'est passé**
En vertu de cette nouvelle loi, de nombreux services en ligne demanderont aux utilisateurs du Royaume-Uni de vérifier leur âge avant d'accéder à certains types de contenu. L'objectif principal est d'empêcher les enfants de voir du matériel inapproprié, comme la pornographie, tout en ciblant un contenu illégal et nocif.

**Impact**
Ce changement signifie des expériences en ligne plus sûres pour les jeunes et aide à protéger les utilisateurs vulnérables. Bien que certains s'inquiètent de la vie privée et de la façon dont la loi sera mise en pratique, l'espoir général est que Internet deviendra un espace plus sûr et digne de confiance pour tout le monde.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les entreprises en ligne commenceront à mettre à jour leurs systèmes pour inclure la vérification de l'âge pour les utilisateurs britanniques. Les utilisateurs peuvent s'attendre à voir de nouvelles invites ou vérifications lors de la visite de certains sites Web ou services en ligne.

**à emporter à une phrase**
La loi sur la sécurité en ligne du Royaume-Uni promet de rendre Internet plus sûr pour les enfants en introduisant des vérifications d'âge et en protégeant les utilisateurs contre le contenu nocif.
articles.personality_title_es: La nueva ley de seguridad en línea del Reino Unido tiene como objetivo proteger a los niños y remodelar el uso de Internet
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
A partir del 25 de julio, el Reino Unido presentará una nueva ley llamada Ley de Seguridad en línea. Esta ley está diseñada para hacer de Internet un lugar más seguro, especialmente para los niños que accidentalmente podrían encontrarse con contenido dañino.

**Qué pasó**
Según esta nueva ley, muchos servicios en línea pedirán a los usuarios en el Reino Unido que verifiquen su edad antes de acceder a ciertos tipos de contenido. El objetivo principal es evitar que los niños vean material inapropiado, como la pornografía, al tiempo que se dirige a contenido ilegal y dañino.

**Impacto**
Este cambio significa experiencias en línea más seguras para los jóvenes y ayuda a proteger a los usuarios vulnerables. Si bien algunos se preocupan por la privacidad y cómo se pondrá en práctica la ley, la esperanza general es que Internet se convierta en un espacio más seguro y confiable para todos.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Las empresas en línea comenzarán a actualizar sus sistemas para incluir la verificación de edad para los usuarios del Reino Unido. Los usuarios pueden esperar ver nuevas indicaciones o cheques al visitar ciertos sitios web o servicios en línea.

**Control de una oración**
La Ley de Seguridad en línea del Reino Unido promete hacer que Internet sea más seguro para los niños introduciendo controles de edad y protegiendo a los usuarios del contenido dañino.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a large, intricately designed digital lock made of interwoven glowing threads, surrounded by gentle silhouettes of diverse children safely playing at a distance, with soft beams of light symbolizing secure online connections weaving through a calm, abstract network background.
